topic.title: Master and Slave Channel Identifier Reuse Scenarios

body.p: In many datapath scenarios there will be master and slave channel id assignments. Depending on the required configuration, the host application will need to reuse the channel identifier from a datapath segment provisioning call to achieve an end to end datapath. Figure 1 illustrates master and slave channel identifier reuse scenarios for client and line interfaces.
body.note: Source for Figure 1 can be found at http://bby1dms01/docmgmt/fileinfo.cfm?file_id=427967

fig.title: Master Slave Channel ID Relationships for Client and Line Interfaces

body.p: Figure 1 illustrates the master slave channel identifier reuse scenarios for the Interlaken interface. The datapath segment for the Interlaken packet interface (PIF) is configured using the g5_api_traffic_ilkn_pkt_prov() API and the datapath segment for the Interlaken ODUk interface (CBRI) is configured using the g5_api_traffic_ilkn_cbr_prov() API. For Interlaken, the user defined channel identifier is always the master. The Interlaken burst control word (BCW) channel number is assigned to the user defined channel identifier when g5_api_traffic_ilkn_pkt_prov() or g5_api_traffic_ilkn_cbr_prov() is called. Note that the APIs allow for provisioning of the fabric ingress (MSCC device to external fabric – Interlaken transmit), egress (external fabric to MSCC device – Interlaken receive), or both directions. The BCW channel numbers do not need to be unique in the ingress and egress directions. The channel provisioning properties configured per channel identifier using the g5_api_traffic_ilkn_pkt_prov() and g5_api_traffic_ilkn_cbr_prov() APIs can be different in the ingress and egress directions. Likewise, the provisioning order is independent in the ingress and egress directions. A SerDes port identifier defines the Interlaken lanes that are used.

As stated above, unique 32-bit user defined channel identifier is associated with the channel specified in the Interlaken BCW for PIF traffic. In addition to the Interlaken burst control word, the CBRI interface optionally supports using a 2 byte, 4byte, or 2 + 4 byte header for looking up 16-bit channel identifier referred to by the CAM mnemonic (content addressable memory) in the mode parameters used when provisioning an Interlaken channel. The BCW channel ID does not need to be unique per CBRI channel in the fabric ingress direction when the optional [2B, 4B, or 2+4B] header is used. Similarly, the BCW channel ID does not need to be unique in the fabric egress direction when the optional header is used but only if CAM mode is selected for the interface when it is configured. The indexes in the optional headers that are used for CAM look up do not need to be unique in the ingress and egress directions (i.e. the same index could be used in both directions). Refer to the transmit controller and receive controller sections of the COPI functional description for flow charts that provide additional detail on the optional header processing.

The 32-bit per channel user defined identifier for a CBRI interface can be associated with either the result of the optional header lookup or the channel number from the burst control word. Mixing the lookup methods is not supported for a CBRI interface as the optional header modes are enabled at the time the Interlaken interface is provisioned.
Interlaken PIF and Interlaken CBR channel identifiers, like all SDK channel identifiers, are global and must be unique for a specific device.
body.note: Source for Figure 3 can be found at http://bby1dms01/docmgmt/fileinfo.cfm?file_id=427985

fig.title: META 600G Master Slave Channel ID Relationship for the Interlaken Interface
Master Slave Channel ID Relationship for the Interlaken Interface
